IV.i.2.A.8.b
.
Examinations Requiring Claims Folder Review
For the reasons discussed in
M21-1, Part IV, Subpart i, 2.A.8.a
, an examiner’s review of claims folder contents is potentially beneficial and encouraged in all claim types.  However, for examinations or medical opinions requested by VBA, the examiner
must
review the claims folder for the following DBQs or claim types:
SC under
38 CFR 3.317
cold injury residuals
former prisoner of war (FPOW) protocol
Gulf War general medical
medical opinions, including etiology opinions in hearing loss and tinnitus claims
mental health examinations
TBI examinations
musculoskeletal examinations involving the
ankle
back (thoracolumbar spine)
elbow/forearm
foot, including pes planus
hand/finger(s)
hip/thigh
knee/lower leg
neck (cervical spine)
shoulder/arm
temporomandibular joint, and/or
wrist
BVA remands
1151 claims
ACE
environmental hazards in Iraq, Afghanistan, and other military installations, and
IDES claims.
Notes
:
For pension claims, sending the claims folder for review is not required.  However, medical records received with the claim relevant to the issue of whether the claimant is currently permanently and totally disabled due to non-service-connected causes must be uploaded into the electronic claims folder (eFolder).
Privately completed DBQs are
not
subject to the requirement for claims folder review for the DBQs or claim types listed above.  Additionally, medical evidence not in a DBQ format that is deemed adequate for rating purposes in lieu of examination, as discussed in
M21-1, Part IV, Subpart i, 2.A.3.b
, is not subject to the requirement for claims folder review.  This is an internal requirement that applies
only
to examinations and medical opinions requested by VBA.
References
:  For more information on
requesting medical opinions, see
M21-1, Part IV, Subpart i, 2.A.7
requesting examinations in claims for SC under
38 CFR 3.317
, see
M21-1, Part VIII, Subpart ii, 1.B.2
ordering initial FPOW protocol examinations, see
M21-1, Part VIII, Subpart iv, 2.C.2
examinations based on ACE, see
M21-1, Part IV, Subpart i, 2.A.4
maintenance of eFolders, see
M21-1, Part II, Subpart ii, 2.A
assessing privately completed DBQs and action to take when a decision cannot be made without additional information that requires an examiner’s claims folder review, see
M21-1, Part IV, Subpart i, 3.A.1.e
, and
review of evidence in connection with medical opinions involving speculation, see
M21-1, Part IV, Subpart i, 3.A.1.q
, and
Sharp v. Shulkin
, 29 Vet.App. 26 (2017).
